newsitem.title: USA: First Data to sell two units for $200 mln.
newsitem.headline: First Data to sell two units for $200 mln.

text.p: First Data Corp said Friday that it has agreed to sell two of its health units to Illinois-based HealthCare COMPARE Corp in a deal valued at about $200 million in cash.
The units to be sold under a definitive agreement are First Health Strategies, based in Salt Lake City, Utah, and First Health Services, based in Richmond, Va., First Data said.
The transaction is expected to close by July 1, subject to regulatory approval, it said.
Healthcare COMPARE is a healthcare services provider currently engaged in acquisitions designed to extend its services nationwide.
The units being sold were acquired by First Data in its 1995 merger with Atlanta-based First Financial Management Corp.

The two companies provide independent health care administration services such as claims administration and related health care management services to the self-insured corporate and government markets.
First Data said it will continue to operate two smaller health care operating units -- VIPS, based in Towson, Md., and EBPLife, based in Minneapolis, Minn.

Ric Duques,, First Data's chairman and chief executive officer, said that while the loss of First Health's earnings will be modestly dilutive, the sale, "will positively impact First Data's ability to concentrate its efforts on its higher growth card processing and payment instruments businesses."

The loss on the transaction and the related impairment to the ongoing value of other First Data health care operations are expected to produce an after tax loss of approximately $200 million, he said.

In addition, the absence of earnings from First Health Strategies and First Health Services operations for the balance of 1997 will reduce First Data's 1997 operating earnings by about $0.02 per share, he said.
As a result, First Data now expects 1997 earnings per share --without considering the after tax loss on the transaction and the related impairment charge--to be approximately $1.58, he said.
